awd_titl_txt: Unraveling Mechanisms of Strongly Correlated Dynamics in Ionic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Alexei Sokolov and Stephen Paddison of the University of Tennessee will combine experimental and computational studies to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms controlling correlations in ion dynamics in concentrated ionic systems. These correlations strongly influence ionic conductivity, and their mechanism remains a mystery. Using a broad array of experimental techniques combined with high fidelity simulations, a detailed molecular-level description of the distinct ion-ion correlations that may enhance or suppress conductivity in liquid and solid electrolytes is being developed. The results of these studies will likely impact the fundamentals of a wide range of ion conducting materials and will be important for rational design of novel electrolytes for various electrical energy storage technologies. The students and postdoc engaged in this project will gain valuable experience in sophisticated experimental and computational research.  The Sokolov research group is also engaged in various outreach activities targeted at K-12 audiences.

This project focuses on synergistic experimental and computational studies of ion and charge transport in ionic liquids, polymerized ionic liquids and organic ionic plastic crystals. Experiments involve Broadband Dielectric Spectroscopy, neutron scattering, and NMR will be combined with ab initio and classical atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and electronic structure calculations. The proposed study will likely provide a comprehensive knowledge of the role of ion size, disparity in the ion and counter-ion mobility, and electrostatic interactions on ionic correlations. The results will also reveal specific structure or compositions that may tune ion-ion correlations from negative (suppressing conductivity) to positive (enhancing conductivity). This study will help to develop design criteria for novel electrolytes that may be utilized in solid state batteries, flow batteries and other electrochemical applications, and provide good opportunities for the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ion and proton transport play a critical role in many energy storage and conversion technologies. Controlling ionic conductivity will significantly improve efficiency of these technologies. However, a detailed molecular-level understanding of the mechanisms controlling ion and proton transport remains elusive. In particular, mechanisms of ionic correlations in liquids and solids that strongly affect their conductivity remain a puzzle.

This project focused on pursuing a fundamental understanding of the mechanism controlling ion-ion correlations in various electrolytes. We undertook a broad range of experimental techniques along with classical and ab initio molecular dynamic simulations. Combining various experimental techniques with simulations enabled us to develop a comprehensive picture of the ion dynamics in various liquids and polymers.

Using our complementary experimental and computational methods we studied proton transport in aqueous solutions of phosphoric and sulfuric acids. Our results show that the characteristics of proton transport in these systems are in many aspects quite similar, but there are fundamental differences. The protons in all these systems are generally moving by very short (about 0.5 Å) and fast jumps between the molecules. This proton hopping provides the major contribution to the measured conductivity in phosphoric acid (PA), where all protons jump at the same fast rate. However, our analysis revealed that some of the protons are moving slower in the aqueous solution of sulfuric acid, and the proton hopping in this case is strongly coupled with rotation of the sulfuric acid molecules, whereas in the PA systems these processes are decoupled.

Our studies of ion transport in ionic liquids, polymerized ionic liquids (PolyILs), and organic ionic plastic crystals (OIPCs) revealed that the experimentally measured conductivity is always lower than expected one based on ion diffusivity. The range of this deviation may vary substantially, from a factor of about two in the ionic liquids to more than 100 times in the OIPCs. We explained this decrease in conductivity by the strong ion-ion correlations: when ions interact with each other they may provide a kind of backflow. In this type of motion, ions have high mobility but provide small long-range charge transport responsible for ionic conductivity.

Among possible mechanisms of ion-ion correlations, we studied in detail the mechanism based on the principle of momentum conservation. In the framework of this fundamental principle, it is supposed that if one ion moves in one direction, then another ion must move in the opposite direction compensating the momentum of the first one. Using this principle, we developed a model and showed how ion-ion correlations depend on the masses of the cation and anion (Figure). Furthermore, we estimated the partial contribution of only cations or anions to the overall conductivity. The latter fact is important since in lithium ion batteries only the current due to the cations plays a critical role in the overall battery performance, while anion mobility is considered as a parasitic effect. Current research work is aimed at suppressing the anion current and increasing the lithium ion transport number.

Applying the principle of momentum conservation, we developed an idea how to increase the cation transport number by varying the solvent concentration. In this case, part of the ionic momentum can be compensated by motion of the solvent molecules. The latter does not contribute to the conductivity, and can therefore be effectively used as an agent to compensate cation momentum and increase the cation transport number. Our model predicts how cation transport depends on solvent concentration and was validated by experimental results.

In addition to these scientific achievements, the NSF funding significantly contributed to the development of human resources and education. Three graduate students and three postdoctoral associates (one female and one Hispanic) were actively involved in this research. One of the students successfully graduated with PhD in 2024, and the second one graduated with MS in 2023. One postdoctoral associate obtained a staff position at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, while another one became a research faculty at UT. Knowledge developed during this project was included in graduate courses taught by the PIs at UT.
